{"id":4406779,"accountId":10,"type":"playlist","title":"Awards","description":null,"date":"2025-09-05T20:51:00Z","location":"","coordinates":[0.0,0.0],"commentsOn":false,"copyright":null,"publishFrom":1757105475421,"publishTo":0,"tags":[],"platform":"PULSE_CMS","language":"en","additionalInfo":{},"canonicalUrl":"","references":[],"related":[],"metadata":{},"titleTranslations":null,"lastModified":1770299064406,"titleUrlSegment":"awards","visibilityOrder":[],"typeRestriction":"TEXT","coverItem":{"id":83956,"accountId":10,"type":"text","title":"How the Premier League's awards work","description":"Find out how the awards for the monthly and season awards are decided","date":"2025-09-04T11:37:00Z","location":null,"coordinates":[0.0,0.0],"commentsOn":false,"copyright":null,"publishFrom":1756964220000,"publishTo":0,"tags":[{"id":8748,"label":"Apple PL News"},{"id":708,"label":"News"},{"id":828,"label":"series:awards"},{"id":12234,"label":"label:Awards"}],"platform":"PULSE_CMS","language":"en","additionalInfo":{},"canonicalUrl":"","references":[],"related":[{"label":"Every Premier League Guinness Goal of the Season winner","id":3529385,"type":"TEXT","sid":"3529385"}],"metadata":{},"titleTranslations":null,"lastModified":1761902839888,"titleUrlSegment":"how-the-premier-leagues-awards-work","visibilityOrder":[],"body":"

You, the public, have the chance to vote on who should win the Premier League's awards for the best players, managers and goals each month and for the season.

There are five categories for the monthly awards:

- the Premier League 2 Player of the Month
- the Coca-Cola Premier League Save of the Month
- the Guinness Goal of the Month
- the Barclays Manager of the Month
- the EA SPORTS Player of the Month

The Premier League 2 Player of the Month shortlist is decided by the Premier League Football Development Panel after PL2 club coaches nominate an opposing player in each of their league matches during the month. The panel then decides the winner. 

In deciding the winners of the other monthly awards, a panel of experts including Premier League legends such as Alan Shearer and Rio Ferdinand cast their votes on shortlists in the three categories.

For the EA SPORTS Player award, the Premier League also asks the nominees' peers to contribute, with club captains casting votes for a winner.

Public vote

The public have the chance to play a role, too, helping to decide the winners in the categories of player, manager and goal.

The public's votes cast in each category will represent 10 per cent of the total votes and will be combined with those of the panel (and captains, for the player award).

So they could prove crucial in deciding who will receive the awards.

Season awards

For the season awards there are four additional awards:

- the Young Player of the Season
- the Most Powerful Goal
- the Most Improbable Comeback

The Young Player of the Season award is presented to the best-performing player aged 23 or younger at the start of the season.

These awards and the Player, Manager, Goal and Save of the Season awards all follow the same process of a combined panel and public vote to determine the winners. 

The Most Powerful Goal is awarded to the goal with the fastest average speed of all goals scored from outside the area, without a deflection off another player. 

The Most Improbable Comeback is given to the team who come back to win from the most improbable circumstances, or where there was the lowest probability of victory. It is based on the Win Probability Statistic developed by Stats Perform, which calculates the chance of a team securing a win or draw by simulating the remainder of the match 100,000 times. 

The PL2 Player of the Season is decided by the Premier League Football Development Panel from its shortlist. 

When are season winners revealed?

The EA SPORTS Player of the Season and Young Player of the Season awards are announced from shortlists on or soon after the final weekend of the season.

The Barclays Manager of the Season is revealed soon after the season finishes.

The Guinness Goal of the Season and the Coca-Cola Save of the Season awards are selected from a shortlist of the monthly winners, plus any outstanding strikes or saves in May. They are announced about a week after the end of the season.

This timescale is true also for the Most Improbable Comeback and Most Powerful Goal awards.

Awards history

The Manager of the Month award began in 1993/94, a year after the Premier League's debut season.

The Player of the Month award followed in 1994/95.

The inaugural Manager of the Month winner was Manchester United’s Sir Alex Ferguson, in August 1993. The Scot went on to win the award a record 27 times.

Tottenham Hotspur striker Jurgen Klinsmann won the maiden Player of the Month award in August 1994.

Man City's Sergio Aguero and Spurs' Harry Kane hold the record for the most awards, with seven each.

See: Awards history

Premier League's Golden awards

At the end of every season there are three more Premier League awards for players who have excelled.

The Coca-Cola Golden Boot goes to the players to have scored the most goals in that campaign.

The Coca-Cola Golden Glove goes to the goalkeepers to have kept the most clean sheets.

The Coca-Cola Playmaker award is presented to the players to have provided the most assists.

See: About the Coca-Cola Golden Boot
See: About the Coca-Cola Golden Glove
See: About the Coca-Cola Playmaker award

Premier League Panel
Kelly Cates, Izzy Christiansen, John Cross, Sir Kenny Dalglish, Michael Dawson, Jermaine Defoe, Dion Dublin, Rio Ferdinand, Chris Foy, Ryan Giggs, Shay Given, Vicky Gomersall, Lynsey Hipgrave, Glenn Hoddle, Phil Jagielka, Graeme Le Saux, Hayley McQueen, Kevin Miles, Gary Neville, Jacqui Oatley, Leon Osman, Michael Owen, Niall Quinn, Jamie Redknapp, Jason Roberts, Jill Scott, Alan Shearer, Mark Schwarzer, Andy Townsend, Stephen Warnock, Theo Walcott, Ian Wright, Barclays representative, Coca-Cola representative, EA representative, Guinness representative.

ype":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":448047,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_PLAYER","sid":"448047"}},{"id":5894638,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":560262,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_PLAYER","sid":"560262"}},{"id":6019582,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":450070,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_PLAYER","sid":"450070"}},{"id":6010765,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":502500,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_PLAYER","sid":"502500"}},{"id":5841948,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":153682,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_PLAYER","sid":"153682"}},{"id":5928575,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":494595,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_PLAYER","sid":"494595"}}],"body":"

Eight Premier League stars have been nominated for the January 2026 EA SPORTS Player of the Month award, and we need your help to decide who wins.

You, the fans, have until 12:00 GMT on Monday 9 February to vote on the EA SPORTS website for one player from the shortlist below.

Your vote will be combined with the choices from a panel of experts to determine the winner, who will be revealed next week.

EA SPORTS Player of the Month shortlist

Yasin Ayari (Brighton & Hove Albion)
P4 W1 D2 L1 G2 A2
Two goals and two assists in four games for the midfielder who has quietly established himself as a key player for Brighton head coach Fabian Hurzeler. Featured in his impressive month was a stunning, powerful top-corner strike against Fulham and another arrowed into the bottom corner in the win over Burnley. The Swede also set up Kaoru Mitoma to score the equaliser in a draw with Manchester City and assisted Pascal Gross in the 1-1 against Everton.

Patrick Dorgu (Man Utd)
P4 W2 D2 L0 G2 A1
In a strong field, Dorgu was the standout player in Man Utd’s resurgence under head coach Michael Carrick. The Dane was phenomenal in the derby victory against Man City, battling all over the pitch and scoring the second goal to secure the result. He then netted a screamer in a 3-2 win against Premier League leaders Arsenal that inflicted the Gunners’ first league defeat at Emirates Stadium this season. Dorgu also provided an assist in the draw with Burnley before Carrick started as Man Utd went unbeaten in the Premier League in January.

Enzo Fernandez (Chelsea)
P5 W3 D1 L1 G3 A1
The central midfielder is not renowned for his goalscoring but began 2026 with a red-hot streak. Fernandez started the month with a stoppage-time equaliser against Man City and concluded it with a stoppage-time winner against West Ham United. He is thriving under new head coach Liam Rosenior – unbeaten in the Premier League since the 41-year-old took over.

Junior Kroupi (Bournemouth)
P5 W3 D1 L1 G3 A0
For brief spells the 19-year-old has been level with Barcelona superstar Lamine Yamal as the teenager with the most goals in Europe’s big five leagues in January. His three last month – including a stunning 20-yard strike against Arsenal and an even better half-volley versus Wolverhampton Wanderers – made his total eight for the season (one behind Yamal) and softened the blow of losing top-scorer Antoine Semenyo to Man City during the transfer window. Kroupi's performances contributed to victories against Tottenham Hotspur, Liverpool and Wolves – Bournemouth only losing to leaders Arsenal all month.

Crysencio Summerville (West Ham United)
P5 W2 D0 L3 G3 A0
The winger hadn’t scored in the Premier League all season until he netted three in each of West Ham’s last three league games of January. West Ham may have lost three times, but two wins – against Spurs and Sunderland – finally gave the club hope that they might still have a chance to avoid relegation. Summerville opened the scoring to set West Ham on their way to the victories, and put them two ahead against Chelsea before Rosenior’s side came back to win.

Igor Thiago (Brentford)
P5 W2 D1 L2 G5 A0
The Brazilian added a further five goals to his Premier League tally, taking it to 16 for the season, as he attempts to chase down Erling Haaland in the race for the Coca-Cola Golden Boot. All of Thiago's goals came in two matches: a hat-trick against Everton and brace versus Sunderland, his contribution pivotal in Brentford’s two league wins last month as they continue to defy expectations in the hunt for a European place.

Harry Wilson (Fulham)
P5 W2 D2 L1 G3 A0
A second successive EA SPORTS Player of the Month shortlist for one of the most in-form forwards in the country. January wasn’t quite as fruitful as Wilson's six goal involvements the previous month, but he produced late winners against Chelsea and Brighton, as well as scoring in the 2-2 draw against former his former team Liverpool. The 28-year-old was the key player again in another impressive month for Fulham in which they only lost once in the league and climbed towards the European qualification places.

Florian Wirtz (Liverpool)
P6 W1 D4 L1 G3 A1
Wirtz is showing signs of the influential superstar he was bought to become at Liverpool. Arne Slot’s side are still not quite in their winning groove but Wirtz scored in draws with Fulham and Burnley, and scored and assisted in the dominant 4-1 win against Newcastle United.

Watch each player's January highlights

VOTE HERE FOR YOUR EA SPORTS PLAYER OF THE MONTH

2025/26 EA SPORTS Player of the Month winners

August: Jack Grealish (Everton)
September: Erling Haaland (Man City)
October: Bryan Mbeumo (Man Utd)
November: Igor Thiago (Brentford)
December: Dominic Calvert-Lewin (Leeds)

VOTE NOW to help decide who wins the Premier League award","date":"2026-02-05T12:00:00Z","location":"","coordinates":[0.0,0.0],"commentsOn":false,"copyright":null,"publishFrom":1770292500000,"publishTo":0,"tags":[{"id":12202,"label":"content-format:short-read"},{"id":12185,"label":"content-type:article"},{"id":828,"label":"series:awards"},{"id":12234,"label":"label:Awards"},{"id":12959,"label":"motm-award"},{"id":12443,"label":"commercial-partner:barclays"},{"id":12352,"label":"franchise:manager-of-the-month"}],"platform":"PULSE_CMS","language":"en","additionalInfo":{},"canonicalUrl":"","references":[{"label":null,"id":2562140,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_MATCH","sid":"2562140"},{"label":null,"id":2562144,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_MATCH","sid":"2562144"},{"label":null,"id":2562142,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_MATCH","sid":"2562142"},{"label":null,"id":2562135,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_MATCH","sid":"2562135"},{"label":null,"id":1,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"1"},{"label":null,"id":8,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"8"},{"label":null,"id":17,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"17"},{"label":null,"id":91,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"91"}],"related":[],"metadata":{},"titleTranslations":null,"lastModified":1770299793176,"titleUrlSegment":"choose-your-barclays-manager-of-the-month","visibilityOrder":[{"id":828,"type":"TAG","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"TAG","id":828,"label":"series:awards"}},{"id":5780017,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":8,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"8"}},{"id":5779958,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":1,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"1"}},{"id":5785627,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":91,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"91"}},{"id":5790779,"type":"REF","data":{"visibilityOrderType":"REF","label":null,"id":17,"type":"SDP_FOOTBALL_TEAM","sid":"17"}}],"body":"

Four Premier League managers have been nominated for the January 2026 Barclays Manager of the Month award, and you can help to decide who wins.

You, the fans, have until 12:00 GMT on Monday 9 February to vote below for one of Michael Carrick, Sean Dyche, Andoni Iraola or Liam Rosenior.

The supporters' votes will be combined with those of a panel of football experts to decide the winner, who will be revealed next week.

Watch each manager's December highlights
Barclays Manager of the Month shortlist

Michael Carrick (Man Utd)
P2 W2 D0 L0 GD+3
Carrick may only have been in charge for two matches in January, taking over as head coach after Ruben Amorim departed, but in those games the former Manchester United midfielder beat the top two in the Premier League and has completely transformed their football. His reign got off to a flyer with a stunning 2-0 victory against rivals Manchester City in the Manchester derby, before Carrick masterminded a 3-2 thriller against Arsenal at Emirates Stadium – the first time the Gunners lost at home in the league all season. Man Utd are back playing the kind of direct, free-flowing football that sets pulses racing at Old Trafford and has led to some early calls for Carrick to be given the job permanently.

Sean Dyche (Nottingham Forest)
P4 W2 D1 L1 GD+1
January was a pivotal month for Nottingham Forest in their pursuit of Premier League safety and Dyche guided them through a tough period superbly. They were on a run of four straight defeats when they produced the most important result of the month with a win against third-bottom West Ham United – their closest relegation rivals – in what could prove a crucial six-point swing at the end of the season. They also battled to a goalless draw with league leaders Arsenal, a match they were not expected to pick up any points in. With West Ham starting to apply pressure, Forest secured another unexpected result in the 2-0 win away from home against high-flying Brentford. Forest’s only defeat came against title challengers Aston Villa.

Andoni Iraola (AFC Bournemouth)
P5 W3 D1 L1 GD+3
After a narrow defeat to Arsenal at the start of January, Bournemouth were deep in a concerning run of form in which they had not won in 11 games – including six defeats – and were about to lose their top scorer and star player Antoine Semenyo to Man City. But Iraola steadied the ship by going unbeaten for the rest of the month to stop an alarming slide down the table. They beat Tottenham Hotspur and Liverpool, drew with in-form Brighton and beat bottom-of-the-table Wolverhampton Wanderers, scoring an average of 2.2 goals per game in a month of thrilling football.

Liam Rosenior (Chelsea)
P3 W3 D0 L0 GD+5
Rosenior, who replaced Enzo Maresca as Chelsea head coach at the start of the month, became only the fourth English manager to win his first three Premier League games, following Bobby Gould (Coventry City), Sam Allardyce (Bolton Wanderers) and Craig Shakespeare (Leicester City). The victories against Brentford, Crystal Palace and West Ham secured nine points that arrested a slump and kept Chelsea comfortably in the hunt for a top-four place. The 41-year-old is winning over any unconvinced fans with his tactical acumen, making key changes to turn defeats into victories, and delivering entertaining football. Chelsea are competing on multiple fronts and, in all competitions, Rosenior won six of his first seven games in charge.

The Breakdown: How Rosenior has won EVERY Premier League match at Chelsea
2025/26 Barclays Manager of the Month winners

August: Arne Slot (Liverpool)
September: Oliver Glasner (Crystal Palace)
October: Ruben Amorim (Man Utd)
November: Enzo Maresca (Chelsea)
December: Unai Emery (Aston Villa)


Six superb saves have been shortlisted for the Coca-Cola Save of the Month award for January 2026, and you can help to decide the winner. 

Watch the saves in the video below and vote for your favourite below by 12:00 GMT on Monday 9 February.

To determine the winner, your vote will be combined with the choices of an expert panel. The result will be revealed next week.

Watch: Coca-Cola Save of the Month shortlist

Alphonse Areola (Wolves 3-0 West Ham)
Djordje Petrovic (AFC Bournemouth 3-2 Spurs)
Jordan Pickford (Everton 1-1 Wolves)
Matz Sels (Nottingham Forest 0-0 Arsenal)
Jordan Pickford (Aston Villa 0-1 Everton)
Senne Lammens (Arsenal 2-3 Man Utd)

2025/26 Coca-Cola Save of the Month winners

August: James Trafford (Man City)
September: Gianluigi Donnarumma (Man City)
October: Martin Dubravka (Burnley)
November: Jordan Pickford (Everton)
December: David Raya (Arsenal)

the Premier League's awards work","description":"Find out how the awards for the monthly and season awards are decided","date":"2025-09-04T11:37:00Z","location":null,"coordinates":[0.0,0.0],"commentsOn":false,"copyright":null,"publishFrom":1756964220000,"publishTo":0,"tags":[{"id":8748,"label":"Apple PL News"},{"id":708,"label":"News"},{"id":828,"label":"series:awards"},{"id":12234,"label":"label:Awards"}],"platform":"PULSE_CMS","language":"en","additionalInfo":{},"canonicalUrl":"","references":[],"related":[{"label":"Every Premier League Guinness Goal of the Season winner","id":3529385,"type":"TEXT","sid":"3529385"}],"metadata":{},"titleTranslations":null,"lastModified":1761902839888,"titleUrlSegment":"how-the-premier-leagues-awards-work","visibilityOrder":[],"body":"

You, the public, have the chance to vote on who should win the Premier League's awards for the best players, managers and goals each month and for the season.

There are five categories for the monthly awards:

- the Premier League 2 Player of the Month
- the Coca-Cola Premier League Save of the Month
- the Guinness Goal of the Month
- the Barclays Manager of the Month
- the EA SPORTS Player of the Month

The Premier League 2 Player of the Month shortlist is decided by the Premier League Football Development Panel after PL2 club coaches nominate an opposing player in each of their league matches during the month. The panel then decides the winner. 

In deciding the winners of the other monthly awards, a panel of experts including Premier League legends such as Alan Shearer and Rio Ferdinand cast their votes on shortlists in the three categories.

For the EA SPORTS Player award, the Premier League also asks the nominees' peers to contribute, with club captains casting votes for a winner.

Public vote

The public have the chance to play a role, too, helping to decide the winners in the categories of player, manager and goal.

The public's votes cast in each category will represent 10 per cent of the total votes and will be combined with those of the panel (and captains, for the player award).

So they could prove crucial in deciding who will receive the awards.

Season awards

For the season awards there are four additional awards:

- the Young Player of the Season
- the Most Powerful Goal
- the Most Improbable Comeback

The Young Player of the Season award is presented to the best-performing player aged 23 or younger at the start of the season.

These awards and the Player, Manager, Goal and Save of the Season awards all follow the same process of a combined panel and public vote to determine the winners. 

The Most Powerful Goal is awarded to the goal with the fastest average speed of all goals scored from outside the area, without a deflection off another player. 

The Most Improbable Comeback is given to the team who come back to win from the most improbable circumstances, or where there was the lowest probability of victory. It is based on the Win Probability Statistic developed by Stats Perform, which calculates the chance of a team securing a win or draw by simulating the remainder of the match 100,000 times. 

The PL2 Player of the Season is decided by the Premier League Football Development Panel from its shortlist. 

When are season winners revealed?

The EA SPORTS Player of the Season and Young Player of the Season awards are announced from shortlists on or soon after the final weekend of the season.

The Barclays Manager of the Season is revealed soon after the season finishes.

The Guinness Goal of the Season and the Coca-Cola Save of the Season awards are selected from a shortlist of the monthly winners, plus any outstanding strikes or saves in May. They are announced about a week after the end of the season.

This timescale is true also for the Most Improbable Comeback and Most Powerful Goal awards.

Awards history

The Manager of the Month award began in 1993/94, a year after the Premier League's debut season.

The Player of the Month award followed in 1994/95.

The inaugural Manager of the Month winner was Manchester United’s Sir Alex Ferguson, in August 1993. The Scot went on to win the award a record 27 times.

Tottenham Hotspur striker Jurgen Klinsmann won the maiden Player of the Month award in August 1994.

Man City's Sergio Aguero and Spurs' Harry Kane hold the record for the most awards, with seven each.

See: Awards history

Premier League's Golden awards

At the end of every season there are three more Premier League awards for players who have excelled.

The Coca-Cola Golden Boot goes to the players to have scored the most goals in that campaign.

The Coca-Cola Golden Glove goes to the goalkeepers to have kept the most clean sheets.

The Coca-Cola Playmaker award is presented to the players to have provided the most assists.

See: About the Coca-Cola Golden Boot
See: About the Coca-Cola Golden Glove
See: About the Coca-Cola Playmaker award

Premier League Panel
Kelly Cates, Izzy Christiansen, John Cross, Sir Kenny Dalglish, Michael Dawson, Jermaine Defoe, Dion Dublin, Rio Ferdinand, Chris Foy, Ryan Giggs, Shay Given, Vicky Gomersall, Lynsey Hipgrave, Glenn Hoddle, Phil Jagielka, Graeme Le Saux, Hayley McQueen, Kevin Miles, Gary Neville, Jacqui Oatley, Leon Osman, Michael Owen, Niall Quinn, Jamie Redknapp, Jason Roberts, Jill Scott, Alan Shearer, Mark Schwarzer, Andy Townsend, Stephen Warnock, Theo Walcott, Ian Wright, Barclays representative, Coca-Cola representative, EA representative, Guinness representative.
